instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: 820 3435 no power, machine was liquid damaged, but over all the board looks to be in decant shape. I have G3 rails, I have s5 rails, missing s4. 0.00v on P5VS4RS3_EN_R, also 0.00v PM_SLP_S4_L...

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Green/orange light present?

The usual culprits checked, U1900/1950/6100. PPVRTC present?

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Yes, i have light on mag safe, U1900 should be good, I get 3.324v on PPVRTC

u6100
pin 1 0.053v
pin 2 0.061v
pin 3 0.000v
pin 4 0.000v
pin 5 0.025v
pin 6 0.025v
pin 7 0.003v
pin 8 0.000v

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Check carefully if there is power cycling on P5VS4RS3. Pluses will be very short and hard to catch on multimeter, best to use a scope. Checked all rails for shorts?

Pin 8 corroded on U1950 is also a common problem that will cause power cycling/pulsing.

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Unfortunately I do not have a scope, with my fluke, it says 0v, but like you said maybe hard to catch. Pin 8 on u1950 looks great. Yes, I checked all rails for shorts.

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Can you post a good clear picture of U6100/U1900 area?

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Looks ok. Well without a scope we can only stab in the dark. Corrosion under SMC? Give it a light reflow with some flux, not full just 150C and let it cook a bit.
